content: hello everybody I am Lorie I am Natalja
Phi's senior data analyst my job is basically to plug my brain into
everything that's happening in that the Phi and then look for weird things I
previously worked in some other places including NPM and Yahoo and if you want
to reach me you can find me on Twitter at Seldon today I'm gonna be talking
about nano Phi's Jam stack Community Survey we ran a survey from March 16th
to April 19th and we collected responses from over 3,000 people people who work
on Jam stack websites we learned a lot of interesting things but a good
question to ask is why should you care about this data the biggest reason is
that it can help you knowing the landscape of the community
that you're in can give you valuable context about yourself if some part of
your stack is giving you trouble it can give you a sense of what else you might
try it can open your eyes up to whole new possibilities of new technologies
that are just coming up then you might not have heard of yet or if you need to
justify technical choices internally it can give you some ammunition to do that
or it could just give you a warm fuzzy feeling that you made the right call the
second reason is comedy my favourite recent thing to find in data is
ridiculous things I love finding truth and stereotypes or contradictory results
I live for that stuff so my main goal today is to help you out but a secondary
but very important goal is to make you laugh at a graph but first some quick
disclaimers 3,000 people is a decent size of survey we believe it's enough to
draw conclusions about the jam stack community but what it's not claimed what
it's not true what we can't do what we're not claiming is that this is true
of web developers generally figuring out what data means is tricky
it means drawing facts together to tell a story and stories can be instructive
but they can also mislead so let's get into all of these things we learned and
try and figure out what they really mean first who are we
demographically damn stacked developers look pretty much the same as web
developers generally and that's reassuring it's a sign that the jam
stack is seeing mainstream adoption jams tech developers show up in every
industry but the largest is unsurprisingly pure tech but the jam SEC
is by no means a tech only phenomenon the top 5 industries were advertising
education media finance and logistics those are not industries that I
associate with jumping on the latest bandwagon jams tech developers also a
wide range of experience this is not a tech just for new devs 25% of job site
developers said that they had more than 10 years of experience relative to their
current role relevant to your current role is a subtle question though right
that's not quite the same as how much experience do you have
so next year we should ask that question more directly but apart from general
experience how much experience do jams tech developers have working on the jam
stack itself it turns out most people are pretty new to jam stack which is
unsurprising because it's pretty new 44% of jams tech developers have been doing
it for less than a year and 22% showed up in just the last six months so jams
tech is seeing a huge wave of adoption right now that's what that huge bunch of
new starters tells us it's no longer early adopters and it's definitely not
late adopters these are the on-time adopters we also asked people where they
work and twelve people said twelve percent of people said at agencies
that's a lot that's way more than agencies represent in the general
workforce natla fine makes it easy to launch lots of websites easily so it's
not surprising agencies which have that model like it one of our more fun
results was when we asked people what teams they were on and then asked them
what teams they interact with most as a way of finding out how workflows work
this was interesting mostly because the answers mostly matched marketing talks
to Doc's as often as dogs talks to marketing sales talks to support as
often as support talks to sales but in a small number of cases there was a big
disparity where one team would say that they talked to another team
that other team would not say that they talked back I debated what to call this
thing the circle of suck the tree of sorrow I settled on the mushroom of
sadness product talks to design but design doesn't get back to them design
talks to Docs but they never reply support talks to marketing but they
don't reply and sales support Docs and marketing all talk to ng and ang never
gets back to them it's funny because obviously these are stereotypes of how
departments that some companies don't communicate well and this isn't what we
were going for when we asked this question but here are the stereotypes
just sitting in the data reported by those people themselves so enough about
who we are what our damn stack developers doing what are we building
using the jam stack our first question on this front was to ask what type of
software people were building a big surprise to me was that fully 36% of
people said they were writing enterprise software that is so many that I broke
them out as a sample and analyze them separately and discover that they're
different in a bunch of ways for one thing they are more experienced
enterprise developers have on average 1.1 years more of experience relevant to
their job than the average respondents in our survey there's a couple of other
places that they differ and I'm gonna mention those as I go to get another
kind of sense of what we're doing we asked people about the size of the
audience the sites that they were working on were built for these answers
were really interesting first 32% of developers said that they worked on
sites for that serve millions of users jam stack sites work at an enormous
scale that is one of the things that we like about them and this is a great
endorsement of that and also that jam stack is in general built for grown-up
use cases but 83% of people said that the sites that they were building were
built for just thousands of users you don't need giant scaling for that of
course damn stack is still very fast and that matters even when you have only a
few thousand users but 63% of people said that they are building sites just
for tens of users when you have only a few dozen users you don't need
performance or scale you know every user by name right you can
DM them and say please wait for the page to load my conclusion from this is that
developers don't just like the jam stack because of the scaling and the
performance they also like the tooling they like the work is that a real
conclusion can I back that up well one way that I could try to back that up is
if I ask people directly what do you like about the jam stack and I did that
it's hard to summarize free text data but I did the most obvious thing which
was to create a word cloud and there's a lot of unsurprising words in there
people like the speed of the site of development itself they like that it's
easy that it's simple easy deploys and security also show up down the bottom
left you can see four words that randomly showed up in perfect sequence
which was really like just love using and that is how we feel about the jam
stack we really just love using it another point of evidence in favor of
the idea that the jam stack workflow is key is when we ask developers about
their priorities as expected performance and uptime are right at the top but next
it comes speed of development the data suggests that people use the jam stack
because it helps them ship it also has some less flattering conclusions you can
draw from this for instance we prefer to ship fast than to make a site secure and
we don't give a about compliance those aren't flattering conclusions but
they're also hard to argue against from my own experience at least and to Perez
devs were different by the way they did prioritize security over shipping fast
another fascinating set of results came when we asked people to rank the hardest
part of shipping a website I personally would have expected that coding the
thing would be up there and maybe deploying it would come second but no it
was the opposite way round Jam stack developers think that deploying is the
easiest part of shipping a website and that coding it is the second easiest
part the hardest part according to Jam stack developers is defining the product
in the first place and the second hardest part is designing it that is a
really surprising result enterprise developers again had a notable
difference here which is that they think deploying is harder than coding which if
you are familiar with deploying in an enterprise environment is not a
surprising result incidentally if you are trying to come
up with a startup idea you're trying to think of something to build this is a
ranked list of the problems that depths want help with they think coding is easy
so maybe don't write another framework they think deploying is easy so please
not another kubernetes service people want help defining products and
designing them they want help with QA with testing with managing copy think
about how you could make those tasks easier for developers so we've covered
who we are and what we're doing so the last thing to talk about is how we do it
what tools are we using before we get into this I want to briefly explain a
metric you're going to see me using here called satisfaction for several of these
questions we asked people two things how much do you use this tech today and
do you want to use it more or less for a bunch of these questions we took the
ratio of people who want to use it more versus people who want to use it less
and we called that the satisfaction score so if people on average want to
use something more than their satisfaction scores over one and if on
average they want to stop using it then their satisfaction score dips below one
note that satisfaction and popularity are not the same often new technologies
have very high satisfaction scores because their users are still
enthusiastic early adopters and vice versa often very popular technologies
have a lot of people who are not very satisfied so a key question to find out
what we're doing and how we're doing it is what programming languages are we
using many people in fact most people use lots of programming languages so we
first asked what your primary programming language was it's no
surprise that javascript was a runaway winner here but there were two surprises
to me first was that typescript is sitting there at 10% I put that question
in there in the first place because I keep running into this phenomenon of
people who think people who write typescript thinking of themselves as
typescript devs not JavaScript developers which is strange because
typescript itself describes itself as being just JavaScript but clearly not
all typescript developers see it that way
the second surprise is that even with typescript and JavaScript together 37
percent of Java of jam stack developers consider their primary language to be
something other than JavaScript there were some variations in there when I
split developers by how much experience they had the newer less experienced
developers were far more likely to have JavaScript as a primary language while
other developers had other languages most frequently PHP when we moved away
from primary language question to what languages in general people use there
were some obvious answers PHP is up there nearly 50 percent typescript is
also a huge deal at 46% obviously people are using all these things at the same
time Python makes a good showing Java less so SQL is really surprisingly high
more on that later and everybody uses bash whether they like it or not so
here's our first use of that satisfaction score that I talked about
this is programming languages ranked by satisfaction not too many people use
rust it didn't make our top ten by usage but the ones who do really love doing it
javascript and typescript were also quite loved but down at the bottom you
can see some sad scores below one the Visual Basic users really hate using
Visual Basic and Perl and Java and PHP are not doing much better even though by
usage they are extremely popular of course it wouldn't be a developer survey
if we didn't ask you what web framework you prefer we have some great data here
because we don't just have how many people use each framework the further to
the right you are the more people use it we also have their satisfaction scores
on the vertical axis so the higher you are the happier people are and the size
of each bubble is the number of enthusiastic users people who say they
use it all the time and want to use it more react score is great on all of
those react is big and popular and loved it's high up and off to the right and
big bubble jQuery is extremely widely used but not at all loved Gatsby is the
biggest full framework in terms of popularity next and next to show up
right next to each other which is not surprising given how similar they
are in their use cases but both flavors of angular are less than loved
angularjs in fact scores lower than jquery in satisfaction and there are two
other outliers in this data the first is eleventy it had a surprisingly strong
showing in our data it has tons of satisfaction but also the smallest user
base it's gonna be interesting to see if next year it has grown and whether or
not it managed to hold on to that level of satisfaction spelt was small and had
middling satisfaction but it had the biggest percentage of people who say
that they don't use it much right now but they want to start that is a good
sign for the future growth of spelt and the last thing that I noted is when I
slip developers by experience is that nobody who had less than five years of
experience has even heard of dojo we ask people how they like to store persistent
data databases markdown files plain old JSON because that's important for static
websites and understanding them the winner here was markdown 58% of people
say they use it sometimes or frequently and also want to use it more
that is impressive customer satisfaction JSON Postgres s3 and mangu are also way
up there but if instead of by raw popularity you instead rank my
satisfaction score you get quite a different picture Redis rises to second
place pushing down JSON and Postgres climbs over JSON as well so to me this
suggests that JSON is very convenient and so a lot of people use it but
full-featured databases are preferred in the long term we also ask people how
their app talks to the server there were three big options and again usage versus
satisfaction are telling us different stories rest has a strong edge in usage
obviously lots of people are using more than one of these but on satisfaction
graph QL just runs away with it there is that's a strong sign for future growth
in graph QL and one final question was about collaboration tools we are
interested in people how people work together there was no surprise and that
everybody loved github but what was surprising was how many people loved
figma I said that collaborating on design is what
people describe is the second hardest part of launching a site and figma seems
to be taking a real shot at a solution this data also reveals that people
really hate email like wow we really hate email but there's one thing we hate
more than email and that is Yammer ouch so what should you take away from all of
this first the jam stack is a tool for
grown-ups enterprise adoptions at 36% the user base is experienced big
established industries are on board this is not a fad the second is that jab
stack is not done growing on time adopters are arriving in droves at every
experienced level in every industry building every kind of software building
apps of every kind for mobile for desktop Jam stack is a big and growing
deal everywhere and we also saw evidence that people value more about gem stack
then building sites that are fast and scale well although they do care about
those things people want to ship quickly and they like the tools that Jam stack
provides to do that also man we hate email and if you're using Yammer
you should probably just stop it's making you miserable just stop so I hope
you feel you've gained some context about the landscape you're in I hope
you've got some warm fuzzy feelings about the stuff that you're using I hope
I made you laugh at least once and thank you all so much for your time and
attention
you
